data.title: Born to Love (1931)
data.meta_description: A pregnant American nurse living in London during WWI, believing her soldier-fiance has been killed in France, marries a wealthy aristocrat so her child will have a father.
data.text:
This begins as a pretty straightforward melodrama and as the stakes escalated it seemed like everyone was going to behave and it would be a real grown-up ‚Äúwe can‚Äôt have nice things because society‚Äù movie. Then a switch gets flipped in one of the characters that makes absolutely no sense and it becomes a suffering mother picture, which everyone loved in the 1930s but just feels needlessly cruel today. We don‚Äôt like to see people suffer anymore unless they are getting stabbed by AI or whatever.

One thing I thought about watching this is how much of what people think of as Japanese social drama shares a shitload of DNA with early Hollywood weepies. By the mid-30s Hollywood imports were‚Ä¶

Her life was just one tragedy after another, huh? üò≠ Constance Bennett is pretty good! This is the first movie I've watched of hers, and I was thoroughly impressed by her ability to express sadness and pain with such complexity that the rather dull and convoluted script doesn't support. Joel McCrea is honestly just there as eye candy. And you know what, thank God he is, because he helps with his distraction from the overall gruesome tone of the film.

Alsooo, I found this a bit weird- the scene where Doris finds out her son has died- is exactly like another movie, also starring Joe McCrea, called Adventure in Manhattan, where Jean Arthur's character says that her ex hasn't allowed her to see her child, and when he let's her, she discovers that the child's dead. Can't tell if it's a coincidence or not.
